On the good side: the city is fairly clean, many places to shop, even more places to eat first class food, and many different types of "neighboorhoods" to explore, all in walking distance. On the bad side:  traffic is horrid, it is extremely expensive, and the city is known for its homeless problem (in one neighborhood we did see people shooting up right on the sidewalk - and there were police everywhere who did nothing).  I like it better than NY and Chicago, but not as well as SanDiego or Seattle.  If you want a dose of nature visit the Capillano Bridge (loved it) and Stanley Park.

title: Love to walk.
reviews: We arrived from the airport to the Four Seasons by car service and walked to and from just about everything else (we did take a taxi twice and took the Aquabus to and from Gainsville Island).  The downtown area is easy to navigate and pleasant to walk.

title: Looks like crystal city!
reviews: I love the walkability of the city., and so much to see and do. The architecture is incredible. Guide books usually include walking tours of the buildings, such as the Marine Building, the Art Gallery, Canada Place on the Bay where cruise ships dock. Buses are available, but I found I could walk to places quicker than waiting for the buses, which only came every 15-20 minutes. I waited for the bus to the Aquarium for 35 minutes!

title: Great clean city
reviews: This was our first time to Vancouver. We thought the city was clean and very friendly. It was easy to get around. They had the subway, bus and hop on hop off tour busses  The city had food truck thought out the city with different types of food. We did a foodie tour which was fun to try many of the trucks. There is so many things to do in Vancouver. We loved the city and will return.

title: Downtown in Vancouver
reviews: We loved Vancouver ! easy to travel by public transport lots of great eateries and breweries from poutine to Atlantic salmon . The people are friendly and helpful and have a great sense of humour too, which is nice. The north shore attractions are easily accessed by public ferries or sea bus and buses to both Capillano suspension bridge and Grouse Mountain.

title: eat eat eat
reviews: we were lucky enough to travel in several places around the world so no wonder why we loved this area...we're still in canada but with hundreds of food from the world...Iran, Korea, Chinese, Japanese...we'll review the restaurants soon, some places you shouldn't miss while over there!

title: alot to see
reviews: we walked around the area and Yaletown, cruise terminal, convention center.  All the sites were wonderful along with the weather-60's.  Starbucks was close by-wonderful.  Pastries and Canadian beers were great.

title: A beautiful city in world ranking
reviews: Vancouver is a modern, bright city with a mix of heritage buildings and modern architure sky scrapers. One could not help noticing there is no graffitti in Vancouver city. Transport is very efficient and there is a diverse culture within the city.

title: Place of Acceptance
reviews: If you are not comfortable with different people, than downtown is not for you. Homeless people with their dog, young people going to bars, tourists, shopping crowd, some people asking for money but never insistent. People always trying to help you and answer your questions. I loved the fun and divergence of the place. Good restaurants, fastfood places, healthy fast food places, stores and best of all nice, kind people on the streets.

title: Safe & Beautiful International City
reviews: Large international city with stunning views from everywhere!  Loads of shopping and restautants to enjoy!  This is truly one of the most diverse large cities on the west coast.

title: It's a Downtown
reviews: I didn't spend much time downtown, but the one night I did go searching for dinner, I have to say I was a little intimidated (I was alone) and ended up back at my hotel anyway.  It's just another downtown, really.

title: Nice but not safe
reviews: You can get a lot of variety in there like Chinese, Indian food; but at night its not safe...there are many homeless wandering and sometimes they even bother you.

title: What a city!
reviews: Downtown Vancouver is well worth a visit - Robson Street is the main one for shopping and coffee shops.  The city's location is what sells it, the sky scrapers on the edge of the ocean opposite the mountains with beaches? What else could you possibly ask for? Some of the architecture downtown is also pretty interesting - particularly the fairmont hotel, Cathedral and head down to Canada Place.

title: Super clean!
reviews: This has to be the cleanest city I've ever visited. If you stay downtown you'll find it's really convenient to walk to many of the downtown attractions. For us, we could walk to Gastown in less than 10 minutes; Chinatown was about 15 minutes away. It's worth the visit.

title: Gotta love it
reviews: Vancouver has whatever anyone is looking for.  Can take an elevator to the top and get a great view of the city  Or  you can walk on Granville Street to do some shopping or people watch.  Lots of stores, lots of entertainment locations, lots to do.  You just have to do a bit of research.  Enjoy the beauty of the city!

title: Beautiful Clean friendly city
reviews: Vancouver is a must to visit ... clean fersh air in a city is hard to come by but you never feel closed in. The streets are spotless and one shop assistant told me that most people volenteer to clean their city.. !!! They are firendly and engaging  unlike other North Americans that sneer "have a nice day " and dont mean it. They really want to talk to you.We really felt welcomed as we travelled around. Downtown is lovely and easy to get around. Places to eat are diverse and you wont go hungry no matter what you like to eat.

title: Downtown showcase !
reviews: The beautiful canada place, the olympic torch,the sea planes small flotilas,the breathtaking view of Grouse mountain,the out of this world view of the entire bay, the astoundingly beautiful snow covered peaks al around,my God , as I said my words and language are failing me!The beautiful age old steam clock across the road,the aboriginals's craft shop,I am gasping for breath !please go very soon.

title: Vancouver is absolutely a beautiful city.
reviews: Vancouver is so diversified with any type of restaurant you wish - seafood is a specialty of Vancouver as we're right on the coast.  Vancouver is one of the cleanest cities in the world, if not THE cleanest - people welcome visitors here.

title: Lupo Restaurant, Vancouver
reviews: We have been to Lupo Restaurant 4 times in recent months and we love it.  The food is excellent, the service is great, the reservation person recognizes us and we are welcomed like old friends.  We were there with 8 other friends before gong to billy Elliott, the restaurant was booked chalk a block and there service was fast efficient, yet we did not feel rushed.  The food is superb, tasty and beautifully presented.  Each time we have taken friends who have not been to the restaurant before and without exception they were all impressed with the food and the service.  Moe was our server on Saturday night and besides being professional he was quite funny.

title: unlike any other city
reviews: very walkable. breakwall goes all around city for walking or biking. impossibly clean. much open space and very green. many water features and flower pots/small gardens.

title: Clean, clean, clean
reviews: What a beautiful city and clean, so clean!  Water, parks, snow capped mountain vistas, friendly locals.  This time it was a three night visit on business, our hotel was near the marina/waterfront making it a pleasure to walk to most of the downtown places we needed to get too.  Definitely need to come back for a holiday, can't wait.

title: Something for everyone
reviews: Three decades ago, Vancouver's downtown was essentially three main streets. Then it moved to five. Now, thanks to all kinds of clever development, the downtown is expansive with a myriad of wonderful restaurants,and lots of cultural hotspots and theatres. Thousands of people live in the downtown and that's because it's generally safe although, like any big city, you need to be a little aware after a certain time. It might be the most liveable downtown in the country although the eastside is also the country's roughest patch.

title: High rise along the water.
reviews: Sky train station is in waterfront area so we were able to walk to our hotel while pulling luggage. Lovely walkway along the waterfront that has a variety of eateries.

title: A Clelan City. How unique!
reviews: If you have the funds to purchase high end items or just like looking at them, take it in!  Due to very good public transportation it's easy to hit many areas of the city even in a short visit.

title: STREET FOOD
reviews: Don't plan your meals, stick with street food. Some of the best food to be had in Vancouver is from the many food trucks found around Vancouver. Check out http://streetfoodapp.com/vancouver for locations. Soho road Naan Kebab was great, also Tacofino, so many GREAT ones!! A real highlight of food in Vancouver.

title: Walkable Urban Beautiful and Interesting
reviews: Can be many homeless or drunkards but not bothersome.  It is interesting and walkable even in the winter rain.  Great discoveries at every turn and wonderful nice people.

title: Vibrant City
reviews: Vancouver is clearly a great city with much to explore.  A three night stay is only a start.  We walked around GasTown and the area by the hotel.  A great city, is a walking city so bring excellent shoes.

title: Safe, Clean and so much Choice
reviews: Downtown Vancouver has something for everyone. Plenty of shopping malls, souvernier shops, Chapters book shop is a must for readers on Robson Street. The Art Gallery has plenty for the art buffs. Queen Elizabeth Theater well worth a visit to see what plays are available. Don't forget Canada Place and the Waterfront. Gas Town and China Town should also be on your list.

title: This is the most beautiful City in the World.
reviews: Sometimes I read these reviews and I feel inspired to write because some of them are just so off base you wonder if the people actually went to the places they write about. Vancouver is probably the most beautiful City in the World. Its situation is specacular -surrounded by Mountains and on the Pacific with an inlet in front and behind. Not only that but the City itself has just the best layout with visually interesting dynamics. Plus it has a huge park that juts out into the sea that takes hours to walk around the outside seawall. This place is magnificant. And - great restaurants, pubs, shops, transit from Airport.Its clean, its safe, it has lovely hotels and great skiing nearby plus tons of beaches- yes, you can ski in the am and come down to the beach in the afternoon and dine at night. You actually can't beat Vancouver. New York has become full of name brands, paris is always grey and quite dull, London is still fun , Amsterdam is lovely but Vancouver is THE best. Ps. I liked Prague too- lovely rooftops- and San Miguel Allende.

title: Exciting Vancouver BC!
reviews: Wow! We had a blast! There is so much to see and do around the city. We walked for miles and never once got bored. We walked along the sea, watched sea planes taking off, took in the sheer beauty of the majestic snow capped mountains against the water, walked to the Olympic torch, China Town, Gastown...all over the place actually and had a blast! There are so many different restaurants to choose from and tons of shopping...from low end prices to high end. The city is clean, cosmopolitan and most importantly, all the people we encountered were very nice and friendly. My husband and I are already planning on our next trip back.

title: Be wary
reviews: This is not Vancouver's best foot forward - apart from Gastown, the downtown/downtown east area is dirty and quite disreputable.

title: Robson Street
reviews: I cant get enough of the brillance of Downtown Vancouver as it is, yet Robson Street is something else! many a shop (shops open til late), many an eaterie, vibrant and alive wih people and near to everything you could need close at hand.  I have visited the city 3 times in 6 years, and always chose to stay in the Blue Horizon on this very street! highly recommended!

title: Lots to see
reviews: Plenty of shopping and restaurants also sightseeing. Most things are within walking distance or a short bus/metro drive away. I wish that our visit was longer because we barely saw a fraction of the sights.

title: Best place to spend time in a beautiful city
reviews: We love downtown Vancouver. You can walk everywhere you need to go. There are great restuarants and the night life is fantastic. A great place to spend a few days in a hotel and relax.

title: Walk & Shop!
reviews: My Hotel was within walking distance to All the major stores. Canada's own, Holt Renfrew, and the newly re-vamped Hudson's Bay Company (fabulous) also, Canada's Aldo Shoe store, and Spain's Zaras! Which I love, & Seattle environs does Not have.

title: Downtown Vancouver
reviews: Great shopping on Robson Street with many known and unknown brands to browse. Easy to walk around Vancouver and very safe.

title: beauty and history
reviews: all the beauty and history you'll need, so many stories, such characters lived then.....and what a great basis for the good times to come !

title: Lots to do
reviews: Very nice, but would recommed staying away from China Town in the Evenings.  Canada Place and Look out Tower all very good.  Comfort Inn Downtown was a good central location.

title: Went to old China Town and Gas Light District.
reviews: We went to the old china town which was fun. There is a great tea shop that we stopped at and had different flavored ice tea. The owner of the shop talked to us for a long time and recommended a great noodle restaurant.

title: Put On Your Walking Shoes!!!!
reviews: The best way to see a city is by walking and in Vancouver that is easy to do.  I could walk all day, there is so much to see, from Stanley park to close by downtown.  Many people flock to "Robson Street" for the shopping but my preference is Dunderave or Ambelside areas.  I do however love sitting at the bistro (outside) at the Vancouver Public Library.  If you have time go and relax.  Also the infamous "Gastown" is cleaned up and trendy!!!!  Lot's of new restaurants and bars,  even great shopping boutiques.  John Fluevog has a great shop in gas town, for all you shoe wh-------!

title: downtown vancouver
reviews: If you want to spend money this is the place to go !Lots of shops ,malls and nice places too eat ,tours etcand a good base for ski ing with 3 resorts nearby and a couple of hours to whistler

title: My 5 days in Vancouver, BC
reviews: I stayed in Downtown area very close to Stanley Park. This is the best area for tourists. Beautiful views of the ocean and mountains. great restaurants, easy public transit, great people, Cherry blossom and Magnolia trees are just mind blowing. Vancouver is A + for enjoying scenic beauty and it's nature! Loved my trio. I would definitely go back again.

title: Great area, beautiful views and well connected
reviews: Having stayed in the Downtown area of Vancouver for a number of days you can easily take advantage of various attractions for miles around. We travelled to areas from Capilano suspension bridge to Squamish. The area is easily connected by buses and the Skytrain.Whilst you would expect the atmosphere to be like packed, busy and dirty like London or New York, we found there was lots of space and the water and mountain views made the area feel very freeing. Plenty of activities within easy travel on foot or bus (just pay once for the day). Enough to keep you entertained for weeks. We instantly felt "at home".

title: One day visit
reviews: Best part of trip was the Capilano Bridge & Park. Food ok, not great shopping (chain stores mostly). Chilly time of year. Beautiful views.

title: What other city has the beach at its door step!!!?
reviews: Always very vibrant & lively, few cities that you see always very busy I guess because so many people live in the center of the city, lots of restaurants to choose from, Shoppers Drug Mart open till midnight most locations, only 1 open 24 hours on Davie Street.

title: It's a city
reviews: Not much different to any city downtown. Green skyscrapers, same stores as anywhere. Quiet though, until lunch time.

title: Something for everyone
reviews: It's a great place, very interesting,very clean. Everytime we looked at a map someone came to assist us. We found the people very friendly. We didn't feel uncomfortable there walking late at night

title: Nice
reviews: It's in a small area so you can walk the whole downtown in a 1 day or 2. There are some not safe areas but during the day most places should be fine.

title: Eating in Vancouver
reviews: The one thing I love about visiting cities is the diversity in the foods available. You could spend as much or as little for your tastes and get a great meal.

title: Beautiful City
reviews: Vancouver is, without a doubt, one of the most beautiful cities in the world.  It does lack in culture and excitement.

title: Fantastic City
reviews: In the heart of Vancouver its fantastic, great restaurants and shops with extremely helpful, friendly staff. We enjoyed fantastic sunny weather Yaletown was our fave district and I would avoid East Downtown unless you like being scared by huge amounts of drug addicts or people with long term mental health problems ...its very sad

title: Something for everyone
reviews: Vancouver is a beautiful city and well worth the visit.  Lots of restaurants, shops and even food carts.

title: People Watching and walking around
reviews: Great city, very multi cultural, lots of unusual food places to sit and have a cold one while watching people go by. On the other hand you can go to a nice waterfront location and have a fantastic romantic dinner. Its all good!

title: pace to hangout
reviews: great places to eat, close to other attractions such as theatre, bars, aquarium, art galleries. By nice weather it will be too crowded and in the winter months there are too many homeless people hangout in front of stores

title: Have it all!
reviews: Fantastic shopping/restuarants, everything on one location, good variety.  Bad for driving,,,best for walking.

title: Walked all over Gastown and Chinatown
reviews: Just loved the atmosphere and the people.  Artists were very nice and bought lots of souveniers!  We went to the Spaghetti Factory in Gastown and had a fabulous meal there.  I would also recommend the Keg for a wonderful steak and that was in Vancouver on Thurlow Street

title: the beautiful
reviews: very nice city surrounded by the sea and mountains.one of the best place in canada for outdoor sports.you feel close to nature

title: Love this City
reviews: Places to walk, eat, visit on good sunny days and very wet days.  As a visitor I would say get on one of the hop on hop off bus tours to get to know where you are going.  Place to hop off for is Gas Town, Yale Town, China Town, English Bay, Second Beach, Stanley Park, Granville Island, Robson Street/Granville Street (shopping), Pacific Centre, more shopping. Lots of different restuarants to try.  East Hasting Street if more old town vancouver, you will see why, but also a very up and coming area.  The Lookout Tower, Waterfront Station, BC Place, Convention Centre are also good places to visiting.  You can walk from Waterfront Station all the way round to False Creek via the waterfront path, it is a long walk with also includes Stanley Park seawall as well but lovely to do on a sunny days and plenty of cafe's on the walk to stop in.  Enjoy Vancouver Downtown :)

title: walk it out
reviews: my wife and i walked through every neighborhood in downtown with no problems. everyone we encountered was nice and friendly. stores do not open as early as they do in the us, so if you are an early riser take note.

title: Great walking city
reviews: Going down to the waterfront on either side was fun. Lots of boats and places to eat. On the East side you can watch the seaplanes takeoff. It's a place where you can get your excercise and not realize it while you see the sites.

title: The Busy Downtown
reviews: There are a lot of stores and building attract tourist here. It's a busy downtown. You may see there are many multinational people around.

title: Downtown vancouver
reviews: Vancouver is very walkable and we certainly explored it. went to Canada Place and had a look round. Went to Gastown and took lots of photos.

title: Very walkable
reviews: Vancouver is a great city to walk...clean and safe. Downside, it rains ALOT.  Explore as much as you can, great neighborhoods and almost impossible to get lost, well laid out

title: Fun Exploring
reviews: Down town is interesting to explore, lots of shops to look in. Allow 2-3 days to explore. Warning watch out for people asking you for money in the street, it happens a lot, so be ready. Just sat no and they will leave you alone.

title: Lovely city
reviews: From shopping on Robson St to taking in the views near the Vancouver Convention Center, there's something for everyone.  Our hotel was in the heart of downtown and that allowed us to walk around downtown and explore the city.  Robson Street has a ton of shops and restaurants.  We loved shopping at both  Roots stores.  The one on the corner doesn't have kids clothes but the other one did.  It's easy to lose track of time while you're shopping here.It's a short walk to the Vancouver Harbor from Robson St.  The views are magnificent here.  The olympic torch and the convention center can be found on the harbor.  Stanley Park is also a mile away.  We walked around Robson and the harbor but got our car to explore Stanley Park and north Vancouver.  I couldn't get over how clean this city is.  This was my first trip to Canada and I'm glad it was Vancouver.  It made such a big impression on me, I can't wait to come back and see more.

title: Yesterday...
reviews: Downtown is really off the beaten track, down Davie to the factory district or along the waterfront to the beginning of Gastown. There's a narrow strip past London Drugs towards the water that's interesting and good for the fashionista's in town. And there's the Four Seasons and the Sutton Place and Robson to the west. Especially little America from BB's to Banana Republic. Forget Levi's, you can go to Old Navy. And Alfred Sung needs to be spanked for his prices.

title: Lively, Charming, and Inviting
reviews: Nearly any downtown area of any major city across the world will have some charm, but few can match Vancouver's. There's a great balance between tourist attractions and local flavor, but what struck me most was how inviting the whole area felt.When my wife and I arrived, it was in the middle of a weekend night, and we had to haul several pieces of large luggage -- we were on a ski vacation -- across six or seven blocks. Needless to say, I was a bit worried, but despite a few loud crowds, there was never a moment where we felt unsafe in downtown Vancouver. The whole area and the local atmosphere invites you to explore every street.

title: Robson Street starting from the corner of Robson and Burrarrd is great for shopping and for dining.
reviews: Robson St. had everything from local Canadian chains such as Roots for athletic wear, to brands we see in the States like Banana Replublic and a slew of others I can't remember off hand. There are wonderful restaurants too!

title: 'Loved It!'
reviews: Vancouver downtown, like any downtown of big cities, has it's share of charm. Most places are within walking distance from most hotels downtown. Be alert after hours especially east of Cambie Street.

title: Great City!
reviews: Lots to do and see - could spend days just walking around enjoying the sites. Lots of people in most areas - so you always feel safe. Lots of great stores and restaurants. Very walk-able and easy to access (even with a stroller!).

title: Wonderful city, beautiful
reviews: Such a great city, with so much to do, great bars and restaurants.Gastown is an old area with cobblestoned streets and some really amazing restaurants and little shops. Granville St is the main entertainment strip. Robson St has all the shops. Head on down towards the west end and Denman st with lots of international cuisine options. English Bay for the sunsets.

title: Old and New
reviews: Visit Gastown with it's cobblestone streets, boutiques, and eateries.  Vancouver is a such a beautiful city.

title: All within walking distance
reviews: Lovely clean and easily accessible city.  Plenty of restaurants and shops.  We walked around the whole of downtown, including the waterfront and shopping district, in a few hours.

title: Best city in the world!!
reviews: Nice beautiful city. Pedestrian friendly. can walk or take tranist (bus or skytrain) to anywhere downtown within minutes. Be sure to visit Robson Street if you like window shopping.

title: A great place to visit, and people watch.
reviews: Vancouver has an eclectic downtown area. There is so much to see and do, both day and night. I personally love it at night. Some of the buildings will be lit up in different colors, it is beautiful. The architecture is a mix of old and new, but there are just some beautiful buildings. Like any city, you have a large mix of people. I enjoy sitting outside at some of the restaurants and doing a little harmless people watching. You will see some characters, that's for sure. Gastown has a lot of great restaurants and bars, and Chinatown is fun to walk through. May not be as fun and exciting for the little ones, but if you enjoy a little exploring, you will have a good time.

title: One way streets
reviews: so  many streets, so little parking...and confusing to say the least. great lil areas of this but wow....clustermuch around this part of town.

title: A beautful city
reviews: Tourists remark on how clean the city is.  Definitely worth taking a city tour to find all the different sides to this city.

title: Downtown Vancouver Massagevancouver.org
reviews: A friend and I decided to treat ourselves to a massage before beginnning our exploration of Vancouver, BC.  We found Cristy Chandler of massagevancouver.org with her spa located in the Scotia Bank building.  Cristy was joined by Jessica who has her own foot spa at Oasis Massage Studio.  Total relaxation at a very reasonable cost.  Our appointments were easily set up through email.  Both specialists were excellent and very in sync with working with us.

title: Great place to spend a weekend..even if you live in Seattle
reviews: Great town,very clean..vibrant with something to do for everyone.We love the wide streets, the glass buildings by the waterfront.The last 2 times[once by speedboat,once by train] we decided that driving there is not worth it..enjoy the boat or the train ride as the public transportation system is great.The only snag was the "eclectic" crowd in Gas Park...a little to aggressive on asking for $.Maybe we caught a bad day.. otherwise not to much different from the crowds by the Pike Street park[less the pot in plain view]

title: great place to spend the day
reviews: Downtown Vancouver is a great way to spend a day. You can go to Gastown which has many cool little shops and the cobblestone streets give it a warm feeling of Vancouver's history. Have lunch in one of the little bistros and some hot roasted nuts from a street vender, which are the best I've ever tasted.You can't go downtown without seeing Chinatown and visit their shops. Feels like a piece of China in the middle of the city. There are wonderful restaurants, lots of shopping, art galleries, Vancouver Library, beautiful buildings and you can even take a break at English Bay.The only caution is when walking in areas, such as east Hastings its better to dress down and don't wear flashy valuables. This is the area where a lot of homeless and drug dealers are doing business.

title: City by the Sea
reviews: Even living here I know I'm spoiled, set between the mountains and the sea, the view is spectacular every where you look around Vancouver

title: Vibrant
reviews: Something for everyone to be found here. Easy to navigate, friendly people. Very clean city. There are shops for everyone here. Food choices are everywhere and you can get whatever you want!

title: gastown
reviews: Plenty restaurants & shops . must visit the gas clock .Nothing to dislike really although alcohol is quite pricey in Canada.

title: Beautiful, diverse and vibrant
reviews: Great city! Accessible, lots to do and see ... and all within walking distance.  The downtown area itself is surrounded by water, filled with old and new architecture and mostly covered in glass.  On a clear day, the mountains make an excellent backdrop.  The cops and firemen are also top notch and very good advocates for their city.  While pricey in most places, if you hunt, there are also plenty of good, low budget eateries too.  Overall, a great place to stay, see stuff, walk everywhere and eat.

title: Beautiful city
reviews: This has to be one of the most beautiful cities in the world and Stanley Park is the icing on the cake

title: Love it!
reviews: Downtown Vancouver is such a great area. It is very cosmopolitan, with lots of great store and restaurants. It's also very beautiful. I would definitely recommend a visit.

title: Downtown Vancouver
reviews: Love Vancouver the sights sounds smells and general great vibe. No end to the possibilities of where to go and what to do, something for everyone. Parking is limited and expensive. Expectation is that you take public transit. Not always convenient.

title: Its one of the most cosmopolitan cities on earth
reviews: Granville Island,Yale town,Gas town,Stanley Park, Grouse Mountain Capalino Suspension Bridge,Great restaurants,cycling paths,Clean water and air,mountains and the ocean.It has it all!!!!!!!!!!!!!

title: nice
reviews: Downtown was neat and convenient, close to everything (transport and sites to see). Lots of food and souvenir shops. Don;t forget to try JApadog

title: #1 CITY IN THE WORLD
reviews: This is by far the most liveable city in the WORLD.  Only Sydney,Australis would be in the running.  Everything is available to visitors.Multi-cultural environment which offers the best in ARTS, SPORTS,RECREATION,MOUNTAIN AND OCEAN LOCATION.......there is everything here that one would ask for.

title: Downtown Vancouver in the rain
reviews: I love the diversity of the restaurants around downtonw Vancouver.  Scroll along Robson and you will find all kinds of restaurants.  You can have crepe for breakfast, Greek calamare for lunch and  Sushi for dinner.  It was also nice to browse the various designer stores.

title: People and Stores
reviews: Great shops, interesting people. Wonderful little food shops. Had a great schwarma. Loved window shopping.

title: BEST PLACE
reviews: Vancouver is a very beautiful place, most of the streets are taken care of very well. Especially the wonderful West End. Chinatown is a great place to explore but be careful of Hastings St. which is actually quite dangerous!

title: So much to look at and so little time
reviews: Loved the trains, no drivers.   Loved the Rock Casino, Sunday lunch is to die for.  Buses are good to get around town, buy your tickets for the train at 7Eleven.

title: Van Heusen Garden - can't miss when you are in Vancouver
reviews: I was in Vancouver to visit my mother and went to Van Heusen Garden in October 2012.  My last visit to the garden was nearly 10 years ago, and there has been lots of uplift and improvements since.  We started with a light breakfast at the caf√© and then walked around the garden.  Please check out the pictures of its many attractions and plant work.QE Park and Van Heusen were the two popular areas for tourists and located right in the Vancouver city, and I love both places.  Even there is an admission charge for Van Heusen Garden, it provides you with a different atmosphere than QE, and honestly it is all worth it.  Believe this place is open year-around, should plan for a trip when you are in town.

title: Beautiful downtown
reviews: Vancouver is a beautiful city, this including the downtown. Don't miss Chinatown, but be careful of the "junkies street": there is a terrible street close by the chinese park, full of homeless people and drug addicts. That's not a urban legend, I have seen it myself and heard a lot about it

title: Beautiful city
reviews: I love downtown vancouver with its clean streets and great shops and restaurants.It is very easy to get around this  city .

title: Amazing Environment
reviews: Shops, Bars, Restaurents and the overall environment is amazing. People are so friendly and you can have easy access to everything.

title: Take the time
reviews: Take the time to walk around the harbor front and the downtown area.  Check out " Gastown".  Lots of nice shopping and restaurants.

title: Great area to walk, shop & browse
reviews: the downtown core is very walkable in Vancouver...lots of shops, restaurants, a big mall, & coffee shops.  One of the best things about the downtown is it has lots of little parks and you are close to the sea in a number of areas....in fact there is a wonderful seawall to walk along with great views.

title: my neighbourhood
reviews: Living in downtown Vancouver, I'm something of an expert on the area. If you are planning a visit and have questions for a local, feel free to ask.

title: AMAZING
reviews: Love it, along robson street you can shop and closer to stanley park you can enjoy a beautiful view. Near Granville the night life is excellent, must see!

title: Vancouver a great destination for couples and family
reviews: Vancouver is a wonderful city. It is water oriented, museum 'heavy', blessed with great natural sights, terrific restaurants, great weather & hotels. And there are a myriad number of attractions that are all terrific!This was the initial stop on a Vantage Travel Tour...called the Trans-Canada Odyssey (from Vancouver to Toronto).  It was an absolutely fantastic experience Vancouver has wonderful places to visit: Stanley Park, Devonair Harbour Park, Granville Island, Gastown, ChinaTown, the Aquarium, Harbour Tours, & much more.Check it out!!

title: Beautiful
reviews: It's always fun to be in downtown Vancouver. There is always something to do/somewhere to go - no matter the time of day. It's busy but not too overly "can't breathe" busy like other large cities. That's why its one of the best places to live :)

title: Used to work right downtown
reviews: I worked in Park Place and love Pacific Centre and all the downtown hustle and bustle - Vancouver is a pretty incredible city after all is said and done

title: Vancouver City
reviews: We didn't know what to expect at Vancouver but were not disappointed. This is a modern, vibrant city, where we felt safe throughout. Visit the harbourside and the restaurants there, go to old Gastown which is full of retaurants and quirky shops, walk to the park, but most of all just drink in the lovely ambience of the place. Fantastic!

title: Something for almost everyone
reviews: When we walked Downtown, it was in a festive holiday mood, and a surprisingly nice day for November.  Shops ranged from high fashion to eclectic boutiques.  It seemed a respite for locals as well as visitors, with shops, restaurants and cafes.  It is a great place to walk, dine and window shop.

title: Vancouver pleases the appetite and the eye
reviews: Vancouver is a diversified cultural city. Loved the access to beaches, fine and ethical dining. Fabulous views. Skiing and winter sports 30 mins away.

title: lots to do
reviews: it was easy to navigate and i had fun, it was raining but still , so cool, i liked dougie dog and the the shops

title: Beautiful Vancouver
reviews: One of the most scenic cities . . . mountains, ocean, architecture, great restaurants, entertainment, culture . . . this city has it all!

title: Vancouver
reviews: You know it is a lovely clean city but when we were there it was raining and cold. Reminded me a little of Melbourne. But I'm sure in summer and spring it must be wonderful to walk around.

title: Boring city
reviews: Its dead downtown in the evenings. Its a city centre and there are much nicer places to go to then this.

title: Wonderful city!
reviews: If you manage to get to Vancouver when it is not raining you will not be disappointed.  It is situated in a stunning location, nestled between the mountains and the water.  There are lots of outdoor activities to fill your days.

title: Diversity plus
reviews: There is so much to see when walking through downtown Vancover.  Yaletown is loaded with all geners of restaurants; Gastown is another "neat" place with the smoking clock and great view of the water when dining or just drinking coffee.  Chinatown is also interesting but one must be prudent in walking certain sections.

title: clean
reviews: So much to see and do! Every day going to downtown vancouver, you will find very interesting sites to see.

title: Vibrant City
reviews: Everything about Vancouver is interesting.  Clean, good coffee, interesting people. Overall good service in most shops and restaurants.  A little pricy in some parts. But certainly a City that needs at least a two week Vacation or if you live in the suburbs take the time to got to the city once a month.  You have no need to go to the same place twice even if many are worth a second visit.

title: Great shopping. Clean efficient city.
reviews: Went I to Holt Renfrew the other day. Fantastic selection of high end stuff especially clothing and accessories. They do tend to cater to the wealthy especially the Chineese Asians. It has a branch of Tiffany too.  The Pacific shopping Mall has all the usual suspects - re chain stores. I am used to London so i didn't find it exciting but  I am sure that there is something for everyone.  If the weather is good walking around this city is a pleasure. If it's not  ( as it is often raining in the winter) head inside one for the shopping centres.

title: Always good downtown
reviews: Many shops on Granville and Robson, easily walkable anywhere you want to go. Clean, safe and lively at night, just stay away from the lower east side of the city

title: Great Town
reviews: Went to Pt Grey Golf Club ... Very Nice. Excellent food. Drove through Stanley Park. Vancouver is easy to navigate around town.

title: High End Shopping or The Dollar Store
reviews: Clean, friendly with a huge variety of shopping and dinning choices. Tiffany's, Coach, Brooks Brothers, CB2 plus almost ever other leading chain is represented within a few blocks. The area somehow is both charming and has a relaxed feel.

title: Lots To Do Here
reviews: There is something for everyone here from shopping, comedy shows, concerts etc.Watch out for the aggressive pan handling, there are a fair amount of homeless people here.

title: Lacking character
reviews: I found downtown Vancouver and Vancouver overall a little boring as a tourist.  The area around Robson  felt  somewhat pretentious, lacking in history and character.  Its just shops and restaurants.  Most of them chains.  It just didnt have an identity to me.  Just stylish people(Asians) dressed up to go shopping.The high rises around seem like cookie cutter architecture.   All the same window shapes, proportions, height etc.Gastown probably is the most interesting. If you are from a large city, (Los Angeles, NYC, etc), Vancouver and its "streets" arent all that interesting.

title: Christmas Fair
reviews: Downtown Vancouver during the Christmas season is an experience unto itself.  The hustle and polite bustle of shoppers looking for the best gift, and temperate climate make the experience fun.

title: GO EXPLORE DOWNTOWN VANCOUVER
reviews: All kinds of things to see and do.  Great public transportation that starts at the airport to downtown (light rail).  Only $2.25. A taxi would have been $40.00 + tip.

title: What else can be said about Vancouver?
reviews: I think it's all covered in the tourist brochures... I like the "atmosphere" best, very "big city" ... I grew up in Vancouver, we always went downtown for everything.. the changes of the years have been a good improvement.

title: Clean, friendly, and lots to do.
reviews: Every type of shop you want from Coach to bargain shops. Get to Robson Street and spend an few hours shopping and visiting restaurants. Get to Davies street for cheaper eats and more variety of foods. Bus system to excellent all taxis are small and energy efficient. People are friendly. Even the few panhandlers are polite! Get to Canada Place for more sites and do not miss a trip to Stanley park.

title: amazing city
reviews: really glad we had a stop over in vancouver to see most of the sights.  there is alot to take in.  the views are really to die for and i understand why people who visit could actually end up staying. everything is so unique and lots of different glass building.  i would recommend taking the time out to see this wonderful city.

title: Such a Beautiful City!
reviews: I spent the day in Vancouver with some friends. We drove up from Seattle, crossed the border, and parked downtown at an all day parking garage. We had such an enjoyable time exploring this beautiful. So many unique restaurants, parks, and architecture to enjoy. We loved all of the glass buildings and walked down to the waterfront for the sunset. Definitely getting a hotel next time and spending more than just a day. Can't wait to return!

title: Intimidating urban experience
reviews: Enjoyable, but not particularly memorable. The view from Stanley Park is excellent and there is good shopping.

title: Some Christmas walkabouts.
reviews: We (a senior couple) did a mini-stay of two-days and nights in downtown Vancouver in late-December, which included several walkabouts of hotels, centres, and the like to experience some of the Christmas spirit.  The stay, which included an evening at 'The Centre for the Performing Arts', to attend a Goh Ballet performance of 'The Nutcracker', was a shared Christmas gift, and much-enjoyed.Much of downtown Vancouver was decked-out for the holidays - here are some of the venues and sights we enjoyed:- Robson Square -- alive & colourful - with public ice skating, and a band performing Christmas and other music.  We did not skate, but we sure enjoyed absorbing the sights & sounds of what was happening there one evening. - Hyatt Hotel -- the 'gingerbread and other pastry creations and displays' in the lobby -- some of the designs and constructions were almost unbelievable - but all, from the simplest to most complex were wonderful to behold!!  And if you stood close to many, you could 'savour' the scents of their makings.  This was the best display we saw during our walkabouts.- Canada Place -- a morning walk along the Canada Trail to soak in some of the harbour sights, and see the Woodward's window displays.  Great natural sights & sounds, combined with the window displays - though the latter, were just 'shades' of what Woodward's used to display in their store windows. - Four Seasons Hotel -- some beautifully-decorated Christmas trees in the lobby.- Pacific Centre -- some more beautifully-decorated Christmas trees in the Mall.Along with browsing some other stores, streets, and the like, we thoroughly-enjoyed experiencing some of the sights & sounds of Christmas in our downtown Vancouver walkabouts.

title: Treasures galore!
reviews: The sighs, sounds & people that surround this area are amazing.The shops a real treat to explore for all those gifts you want to share with family & friends let alone the ones you want to keep for yourself! The Gastown Steam Clock is unbelievable! Every hour it does a complete song & with a homeless man giving you the most wonderful talk about this clock, I'm so glad to give my small amount of change for all the effort he gave!

title: Vancouver...
reviews: what can you say. It's a beautiful city in a beautiful province. Even when it's raining...there are so many great eateries and shops to drop in until the sun comes out.

title: Noah says-----downtown is great!
reviews: Spent a Saturday night downtown after our hotel checkin.  The sidewalks were alive with people everywhere.  Many shows to see and many popular reasturants to choose from.  A beautiful downtown area.

title: using the sky train to explore the central core
reviews: we came in on the Canada line and got off at central station and that leads you into all sorts of shopping...when you have had enough go out on the street and Robson Street is near by with all its stores....walk down to the west till you reach Denman street.........both these streets are full of shops and resturants....one we like, a new concept on Denman is a store full of pedal supported displays full of dried fruits and nuts.........you take a bag and take a scoop out of any of the displays ...you pay by weight....a nice snack to carry down to Enlish bay and watch the people walk by and enjoy the water view....stop at Starbucks on the corner before you decide to walk back to a sky train station and head home after a long enjoyable day.

title: Same as any other modern cities downtown
reviews: Its a city centre like so many others, shops,  bars restaurants, whatever you want. But there is nothing standout-ish about Vancouvers downtown area

title: A Cut Glass City in a Platinum Setting
reviews: The vista here is breathtaking, unfortunately the architecture is not complementary of the amazing location - on a saltwater inlet, with beaches, rivers, towering mountains across the bay and the beauty of 500 acre Stanley Park on the doorstep.

title: one of the best in the world
reviews: It's my second time in Vancouver. Being in downtown there is infinite pleasure. Nice walking, good coffees, nice food. Mixture of different faces and ethnic backgrounds, very civilised. Some areas are a bit excentric if not rough though ...

title: Scenic and walkable, but increasingly aggressive homeless population
reviews: We travel to Vancouver once or twice a year, and one of our favourite things to do is walk around downtown, enjoying the restaurants and taking great photos. The main problem is that the homeless population, which has always been present, is becoming more aggressive. For example, during our most recent trip, when we silently walked past a man who approached us and asked for money, he suddenly began spewing profanities and insults because we ignored him/ wouldn't give any money. He started following us down the street until we ducked into our hotel lobby. We are seasoned travellers and do not scare easily, but it has been disconcerting that we are feeling a little more on guard with each trip to Vancouver.

title: How do you rate a city???
reviews: Downtown Vancouver is the like most cities....its where things happen.  Shopping, museums, malls, and nightlife.  Whatever you want its there......Easy to access by sky train from any rural area .  Good theatre, lots of restaurants...a good time overall.

title: Something for everyone
reviews: Didnt spend a lot of time downtown but looks like there is something for everyone. Good bus service and subway connections makes it say to get around.

title: Classy big city
reviews: Easy to get around with free trolleys and city guides everywhere.Very cosmopolitan with a wide variety of shops, eateries and many hotels.  Very clean area and well maintained gardens and streetscape and friendly people.  However there are homeless? people on every corner some with animals, cats and dogs and signs requesting money etc.some I found very distressing.  This area has everything for the visitor & the city dweller including a magnificent harbour and cruise terminal.

title: Easy to walk around and soak up the atmosphere
reviews: Very compact and some interesting buildings such as the cathedral (better inside than out), the Art Deco Marine building, Fairview hotel, Canada Place. The tourist office opposite Canada Place are extremely helpful and offer a good deal on the trolley bus hop on hop off city tour.

title: Things to do
reviews: Summer in Vancouver is an absolute rush. Festivals around every corner; music in the streets and happy people. Wonderful running routes, everyone uses. A trip up to Whistler and surrounds is recommended. Saw bears in the wild. Well worth a visit.

title: Nice Stroll...
reviews: I'm not sure what warrants "Downtown Vancouver".  However, we've walked Canada Place and watched the cruise ships go in and out.  We've also walked around Gas Town, named after Gassy Jack.  Be sure to stop at the gas clock for a photo op!  There are many shops and restaurants in this area.  A short stroll over is China Town, which is always a wonderful place to shop or eat.  The small park in China Town is a beautiful area to sit and admire the koi and just soak up that peaceful feeling.  Although the large department stores of yesteryear are gone (mostly), there are still many places to shop and eat "downtown".  There are a few nice parks, plenty of hotels, and some nice movie theaters as well.  Quite often, there are demonstrations or parades.  We hit a very strange one on our last trip -- a "Zombie Parade".  Nearby, there is also Stanley Park.  Here you can enjoy the totem poles, see lots of geese - plus other small critters - also watch the cruise ships, bike, hike, soak up the sun.  Plus they have a wonderful little aquarium in Stanley Park.

title: Shoppers Dream
reviews: If you LOVE to shop this is a DREAM!!! There is just about everything you could imagine there...High end, Low end , and everything in between.  Very clean, pedestrian friendly downtown.  Put on your cutest walking shoes and shop till you drop!

title: Vancouver Central
reviews: The city of Vancouver is truly a glass wonder. The buildings are beautiful & modern and the atmosphere is always urban and chic. Don't let a little rain stop you.

title: Wonderful City
reviews: Vancouver is a great city for walking about and is easy to see everything by foot , the best way is to take a city bus tour and get points of reference and then the rest is simple try and stay at the bottom of davies street next to stanley park ( best Western ) and you are central for everything , good food , nice pubs , Tim Hortons ( Cheap Breakfast ) also easy access for the road to whistler and beyond great place

title: GasTown
reviews: Check out this little corner of history in Vancouver. Many stores to visit and lots of history to learn. The steam clock is fantastic, don't miss it!

title: Shopping and Circle Craft Fair
reviews: Really enjoyed the circle craft fair.  Only complaint is I only heard about it through a friend.  Advertising seemed to be lacking?

title: Exciting!
reviews: What nightlife...no other place like Vancouver`s downtown. Rivalling many of the world`s greatest cities, for sure. Lights and sounds not to be missed.

title: Awesome place if you want to party
reviews: I spend some holidays at downtown Vancouver and it was great, there are lots of places to eat for 2 dollars, there's also a great mall there where you can take the skytrain if you want to get anywhere

title: European Feel
reviews: Wandering the streets of Vancouver is great for people watching.  Pedestrians are from every point on the globe.  But it seems the stop smoking campaign has not come to Vancouver yet.  So many smokers!

title: Clean and Friendly
reviews: Vancouver was fabulous!!! We will return during the ski season to take a mini trip to Whistler.  We would highly recommend a visit!!!

title: A Work In Progress
reviews: Many of the downtown retail stores fled to the suburbs some years ago. Just now undergoing revitalization and new bigbox stores. Some nice restaurants west of Granville Street.

title: Very Clean, friendly staff in all stores
reviews: Another very enjoyable experience. The people in Vancouver are so nice and helpful. We enjoyed everything about our downtown experience.

title: Canadian Mounted Police store
reviews: Pricey, but interesting clothes and other tourist items in concert with the theme.  I  was surprised to find this novelty store between the convention center and the Canada Line/Sky train station..

title: World Class City
reviews: Did a walk about in Gas Town with some out of town guests on the weekend and, in spite of the weather, they were impressed.  We stopped in at Mahony and Sons after Gas town and enjoyed a beverage and the comings and going on the waterfront.  One of our guests had never seen an aircraft take off or land on water.  Always neat to show someone something new !  They were amazed that the 2010 Olympic Cauldrun is still there and, on occasion, working.  Currently Vancouver is going through a "Romance the Cyclists" phase and, as a result, becoming less and less car friendly so park it and take transit.  We included a walk about on Granville island, reached by one of those mini water taxi shuttles, and a tour through the market as well as lunch at the Dockside.  All in all a great day with friends.

title: exciting places to visit
reviews: great exciting place to visit and the atmosphere there was vibrant being  a popular place  for tourists especially from Asia.Group tours were abundant. Great places to eat with bistro and specialty bars in numbers. Popular places around the Canada Place and waterfront. Free museum at Canada Place.

title: Lovely restored areas!
reviews: Coming from an "heritage" city in Australia, we really appreciated some of the old areas of Vancouver and the effort that has been put into REstoring and not DEstroying the lovely old buildings and shopfronts.  In particular we really appreicated the steam clock - but disappointed that it couldn't quite allow itself to "go off" whilst we waited for the hour to do its thing!  We were a little disappointed with the whole Chinatown area though and thought it a bit over rated for what it offered.....but I guess it is all part of history!

title: Pretty city
reviews: Very easy to get around. Easy to walk the area. Lots of eateries and bars or pubs. Very nice around the waterfront n worthwhile to catch a water taxi for a different view of the city.

title: Loved this city
reviews: Lovely city in a lovely setting.  Liked all the green spaces surrounding the buildings and the water and mountain views.

title: As advertised
reviews: We were told that Vancouver was a beautiful city and it didn't disappoint.  We walked all over enjoying the buildings and the ambience.

title: Walk, don't ride in downtown Vancouver
reviews: Downtown Vancouver is clean and well-laid out, so getting around with a map was easy. Great shopping opportunities and lovely architecture and parks.  If it's souvenirs you're after, shop in Gas Town before going to Granville Island, where the prices are considerably higher. My daughter enjoyed the John Fluevog flagship store. Beware of panhandlers near Gas Town.

title: Nice downtown and an elegant environment
reviews: The downtown is so organized and spacious I loved it all and I'll visit it any time I get the chance to do so

title: Just Like Home
reviews: We live in Melbourne Australia, and were amazed at the similarity between Vancouver & Melbourne. While we have rain, Vancouver has 'Liquid Sunshine' but we were ready with our umbrellas and just loved every minute.

title: Lots to see
reviews: Recently spent 5 days in downtown Vancouver - enjoyed it very much.  Lots of great shopping, good dining, great coffee!  We felt very safe - early morning, late night - never felt threatened or that we should not be out.

title: Visiting Vancouver? Stay Downtown!
reviews: We rented an apartment in Yaletown and absolutely loved the convenience to downtown attractions. Public transportation options in downtown are excellent, and walking is always a great option. As with any big city, there are areas to avoid at night, but during the daytime a walk through Gas Town, Yaletown, Chinatown, Canada Place and Stanley Park are highly recommended.

title: Walk ,shop, people watch
reviews: Great stores, restaurants, tourist sights, bring your walking shoes and an umbrella.Fantastic hotels , great art gallery

title: A Must DO!
reviews: We went to Vancouver on our way to an Alaskian cruise.  This was a MUST DO on our list (bucket List).  It was absolutely worth the trip.  If the surrounding mountains and lake sites do not woo you, the city lights and high raisers and shops, restaurants will!  Gastown is a very "unique" place to go to.  We absolutely LOVED Vancouver!  We spent a week there in a condo and flet like one of the locals!

title: Downtown, one of Vancouver's jewels!
reviews: Brreathtakingly beautiful...lots of great shopping and great restaurants.Even from Downtown Vancuver,you can see the ocean and the mountains.Can't beat it on a sunny day...Nature's perfection!

title: Panhandler asking for spare change to kill Bieber
reviews: Vancouver is a tourist city so its easy to exchange money unlike here in the States. Public transit is great.  Not much too say- its the downtown of a big city: dirty parts, lots of shopping, lots of food, homeless, expensive buildings.

title: Loads happening
reviews: Shops are OK - as Sears was closing down and the only stuff left was jumble. However, some of the boutique shops are worth a look around. Walking around, you feel safe and there is usually something happening in the early evening

title: NEVER AGAIN
reviews: Spent an hour or so in downtown Vancouver and I was PETRIFIED. On a Sunday afternoon, My wife and I witnessed 2 people being mugged, a fist fight and lots of people living on the streets, doing drugs. I am sorry such a nice city is going thru such tough times. Not a safe place.I would stay away from it. Police officer and cars chasing the perpetrators offered a 3rd-world scene. There are way better places in BC.

title: Aggressive Panhandlers
reviews: Loved the unique stores and shopping on Robsin Street and in the Pacific Centre, however the people asking for money were very push and followed us.  I was surprised they were in the mall and in the food court.  The swearing and forwardness was a bit unsettling and I wanted to go back to the hotel.

title: Robson Street
reviews: We liked to walk along the Robson Street. It was very busy time of the year so there were many people around and many sops open late. had a good time.

title: Lots of Shopping
reviews: Lots of shopping in the shopping district.  Lots of chain stores and some boutiques, and an embedded mall.

title: Alot to see in Downtown.
reviews: After taking a less than stellar sky train ride to Yaletown, I went west to Davie and Denman,I had a rest break at the beach,but I was actually nearby the entrance of Stanley Park. A very acceptable weather non rain day on Saturday afternoon. Cars actually stop for traffic and people love cycling on roads and bike paths. Across the road were these Giant statues of laughing metal men took some snaps shots  and later boarded a public transit to Chinatown. The bus had various sizes and some were electric wiring on top besides gas buses The transit fare was affordable and you get a electronic bus ticket as a souvenir back.Wow,Chinatown is an actual Chinatown.  It went on for several blocks. The site of Sun Yet Sen park  is pleasant,The smell of dry goods, the sounds of people chattering and playing mahjong.Around the corner is Hastings street, every city has their own non recommended tourist attraction.The city's eyesore is Hasting. No one bothered me for a light or spare change. Just across the soccer park was the Rogers Center and the BC place all a very good outing for a Saturday stroll.

title: Vibrant Vancouver
reviews: We stayed downtown on our Vancouver vacation, and it was wonderful!  The waterfront beckons, and the downtown vibe is great!  From street vendors to local office workers to tourists to shopping, the ambience is invigorating!  Even if you stay in another area of town, make a point of spending time downtown.

title: Come on down!
reviews: What isn't to love about downtown Vancouver these days. Since the 2010 Olympics, it has been a great place to discover and visit. Tons of clubs for the youngins, and nice restaurants everywhere. From Granville to Robson street to the gay district on Davie st, theres always fun to be had. Parking is very expensive tho, transit downtown if you can.

title: must do gastown
reviews: Gastown is the 'older' district in Vancouver downtown and by far my favourite part. It's a few quaint streets which are now filled with restaurants and pubs. Great place to grab a bite to eat at night and check out cute shops.Be careful to not stray too far towards Chinatown from there. Between Chinatown and Gastown is one or two blocks which seem to be filled with homeless people, junkies and drug dealers at night. They didn't bother us when we walked through there but it was very uncomfortable.

title: Marine Building - foot of Burrard ART DECO!!!!!
reviews: This is my favourite building in Vancouver bar none.  At one time Vancouver's City Hall it is still in full use with a penthouse apartment as the only place you can live/stay, the rest is business.  You can start with the exterior of this wonderful Art Deco building, there are Marine nuances everywhere.  If you Google up Marine Building Vancouver you'll see images that say at one glance what would take me paragraphs to explain.  When you go DO NOT forget to take the elevators they are replete with inlay and beechwook just for a start!  This heritage building is the best this city has to offer.

title: Vibrant city
reviews: We live just outside the city, and it's always fun to go check it out. Skip the big mall, though shopping is great, and walk Granville, or check out Robson. The Vancouver Art Gallery is amazing, the Canadian Mint is right there, and the waterfront is amazing.

title: granville island
reviews: i thought all the shops were awesome, particularly the location.  the broom shop was so unique.  the farmers market had such a great selection of veggies, fruit & a hice  selection of different foods you could eat for lunch or dinner.l

title: Vancouver highlights
reviews: Long weekend in Vancouver (BC)As the Labour Day holiday was approaching this year, Vera and I were making plans how to spend this long weekend in neighboring province of British Columbia. Our plan was to drive there and visit our friends in Langley (BC) and we also wanted to finally tour the city of Vancouver. I knew, it was going to be a long drive, but I like driving so off we went on Friday morning (I had an extra day off from work) via Jasper and Kamloops on this 1000 km journey through western Canada.Vancouver was our destination for this journeyHighway journeyWe took Yellowhead highway 16 to Jasper and continued (without stopping) on highway 5 through Valemount and Clearwater, all the way down to Kamloops. We then continued down Highway 5 (the Coquihalla Highway) down through Merritt and Hope to Chilliwack. Some say this road is a toll road, but we didn‚Äôt have to pay for this road (Sep 2012). It is a good, double lane road, though. From Chilliwack I drove on the highway 1 straight towards Vancouver and took exit for Langley.We arrived in Langley before dusk and our friends were happy to welcome us with a glass of home made vine at their newly renovated house. We discussed our plans for the next day and went to bed early, so that we‚Äôll be well rested for the long touristy day in Vancouver.Sea-to-Sky HighwayLangley is a short 45 minutes drive from Vancouver and we made to the city by avoiding the busy highway 5 where there are always traffic issues. Instead we used the ‚ÄúSea-to-Sky Highway‚Äù, which is actually highway 99. This highway travels along the scenic Pacific Ocean vistas, bustling communities and parks. Smooth moving traffic at the times we‚Äôve been on it. The ‚ÄúSea-to-Sky Highway‚Äù is the name given to the section of Highway 99 starting just north of Horseshoe Bay. From Horseshoe Bay, the highway travels along the coast of Howe Sound for 12 km to Lions Bay, north for another 21 km to Britannia Beach, and further north for 11 more km to Squamish, at the head of Howe Sound. We left the highway once we reached the city as we were heading towards the North Vancouver. We wanted to visit well known tourist attraction ‚ÄòCapilano Suspension bridge‚Äô.Arial view of VancouverVancouver CityWe‚Äôve been in Vancouver previously, but never had time to be a real tourists and see the city from that perspective. Here is my short story and how it went this time‚Ä¶Our 2-day itinerary of Vancouver began in Vancouver‚Äôs North Shore where we visited Capilano Suspension bridge. From there we went into Stanley park and stopped at the downtown peninsula in the heart of the city to walk the Vancouver‚Äôs Port Metro and Gastown area. All those spots provided a small glimpse of what makes Vancouver Canada‚Äôs most beautiful city.Vancouver Yacht clubVancouver is, after all, one of the cities that routinely tops those lists of the world‚Äôs greatest places to live. But beyond the breathtaking snowcapped crags, city-hugging beaches and dense waterfront forests lies a comparatively young metropolis that‚Äôs still trying to discover its true identity ‚Äì less than 150 years after a ‚Äògassy‚Äô Englishman rowed in and kicked it all off with a makeshift pub.Arial view of Vancouver harborCapilano Suspension bridgeYeah, it‚Äôs a tourist trap but I like to be a super tourist and do touristy things when I travel. At $34 a pop to enter it is not cheap. Food is expensive in the park but you get a free poncho if it might rain‚Ä¶ lol! It didn‚Äôt when we were there‚Ä¶ instead we had a great weather! It‚Äôs a great look at nature for someone from the big city like us.Capilano Suspension bridgeThe park itself is quite scenic and has some interesting activities: network of short suspension bridges between trees, a semicircular bridge jutting out from a cliff, some cool informative displays, and of course the Capilano bridge. But on a weekend it was full of tourists, who thought nothing of holding up everyone behind them to get several shots of their kids with no one else in the frame. That made it for very slow bridge crossing. If you‚Äôre sensitive to heights and bridge swinging, you shouldn‚Äôt go.Swinging Capilano Suspension bridgeSemicircular bridge jutting out from a cliffSemicircular bridge jutting out from a cliffThere are no true hiking trails, and the park is not very big, you will cover all the ground in about 90 minutes. I would say it would be worth it for ~$15, but the fee is extortionate and a true nature lover would be better served elsewhere. I can see how it is great for families or people looking for a manageable nature walk. If you do go, take your time and explore everything, the views throughout are lovely.Network of short suspension bridges between treesCurrent admission to the bridge is $34 for adults, $27 for teens, and $12 for kids 6-12. We could go free to Lynn Canyon. What do I think beauty is worth? Can I afford this much money for this one attraction though? You could argue there are more bridges and things to see at Capilano, but the thrill of crossing a suspension bridge was the experience we were looking for. Going to the free, public Lynn Canyon bridge would fit the bill just fine‚Ä¶ perfectly even. So, next time I‚Äôll go there‚Ä¶Capilano Bridge HistoryIt was about 1890 that George Mackay discovered the spot, where Capliano Suspension Bridge now stands. Impressed by the beauty of the land, he built a cabin for himself and his wife. Then, with the help of local natives and a team of horses, he pulled taut the first cedar plank and hemp rope bridge 450 feet across and 230 feet above Capilano River.Mackay‚Äôs friends began their journey to the bridge by crossing Burrard Inlet abroad the S.S. Senator. A long trek up the rough trail that is new Capilano Road led to their being dubbed, Capilano Tramps. The encumbrances of their dress did little to deter the spirited adventurers, who steadily visited the bridge. It was such a popular attraction that a second, and more secure, wire bridge was built in 1903. Another wire bridge, with both cable ends firmly encased in concrete, was built in 1914.In 1911, the Tea House (now the Trading Post) was built on the edge of Capilano Canyon. Later, during 1930s, bridge owner, Mac MacEachran, initiated the tradition of inviting local natives to place their totem poles on the grounds. The totems, you see here today, are maintained in the exact condition, in which they were received about 1940. This is unlike many of the poles, you may see elsewhere, which have been allowed to deteriorate with the passage of time.At the end of cliff walksBeautiful scenic canyon deep down under the bridgeDuring this 1930‚Ä≤s Depression, two Danish carvers, Aage Madsen and Karl Hansen, arrived at the Bridge to sell their craft. In return for provisions and shelter in a small shack, on the far side of the Canyon, they carved the life sized native Indian statues that are scattered throughout the Park. The European perception of natives is apparent in the Plains Indian attire of the figures.The only exception is the carving of Mary Capilano, who is dressed in typical West Coast fashion with papoose Mathias Joe Capilano on her back. Mary was the only local native the two carvers had actually met.In 1956, the present bridge was built. This time the pre-stressed wire cables were encased in 13 tons of concrete at either end.Several attractions have been added to the Park in 1990s, including The Story Center and Living Forest Exhibits, the cantilevered deck along the Canyon edge, the big house native carving center, the Pioneer Garden and the Loggers‚Äô Grill‚Ä¶Stanley ParkLook at an aerial map of Vancouver and you‚Äôll see the huge patch of green dominating the downtown peninsula. This green patch is Stanley Park Vancouver, the gem of the city that makes Vancouver what it is. The park is nearly 1000 acres in size, reflecting the city‚Äôs love for nature and appreciation for preserving green spaces, even in such a quickly-growing area.unner statue of Harry Jerome (Canadian Olympian three times: 1960, 1964 and 1968) in Stanley ParkStanley Park is the largest urban park in North America, and opposed to other famous North American parks such as Central Park in New York, Stanley Park Vancouver is not just a manicured sprawl of lawns and neatly planted trees. What makes Stanley Park unique are the amazing views on the wrap-around Stanley Park seawall, the dense rainforests, the marshland, and the beaches.Stanley Park mapThe Stanley Park seawall follows the park along the Oceanside with bike and pedestrian pathways. Every day joggers, bikers, rollerbladers, walkers and others out to enjoy the view can follow the Stanley Park seawall for 10.5 km along the beach. Away from the seawall and the perimeter of the park, a dense forest grows, where few people actually spend much time. Like other parks, there are also plenty of lawn areas to play soccer or toss a Frisbee, and a number of beaches for sunbathing and volleyball. On this beautiful and sunny September‚Äôs Sunday, when the temperature was reaching almost 30 degrees, park was really crowded and people were everywhere. We drove around the park as it was difficult to find parking. It was still enjoyable‚Ä¶Lions Gate Bridge viewed from Stanley ParkFamilies enjoying the bike ride in the parkStanley Park history begins in the early stages of the city‚Äôs development. In 1886 the city council made the insightful decision to turn what had become a military reserve into a park. The towering cedars, swamp lands (now known as Lost Lagoon), and prime water-front property were all set aside for the ‚Äúuse and enjoyment of people of all colors, creeds and customs for all time,‚Äù according to Lord Stanley, Canada‚Äôs governor general from1888 to 1893. Stanley Park history set the tone for the way the city would evolve; deeply committed to the preservation of its natural resources.To best enjoy Stanley Park, try renting a bicycle at one of the many bike rental stores along the way. To walk the entire Stanley Park seawall it takes about two hours at a brisk pace, so don‚Äôt expect to be able to breeze through the park in a few minutes. Besides, there is so much to do and see in the park, you‚Äôll want to take your time.There are a number of restaurants in Stanley Park where you can enjoy a delicious meal with a stunning view. Try afternoon tea at the Rose Garden or lunch at the scenic Sequoia Grill (formerly the Stanley Park Teahouse). The Fish House has delicious seafood in a beautiful heritage house. At the Prospect Point viewpoint there is a nice cafe. While touring around the park, make a stop at the totem poles, and plan some time to see the Vancouver Aquarium.View on downtown Vancouver from Stanley ParkIf you decide to tackle Stanley Park Vancouver on foot, the Translink bus system can make the distance between attractions much quicker. Look for the ‚Äò‚ÄôStanley Park Shuttle‚Äô‚Äô which runs on a fifteen-minute schedule daily from June through August. The bus makes fourteen stops around the park.Cruise ship docked in Vancouver PortCruising Port Metro VancouverAfter visiting Stanley Park, we found parking at the Vancouver Convention Centre. From there everything we planed to see was on a walking distance. For more than 30 years, the Port Metro Vancouver has been a leading homeport for Alaska cruises. The Port‚Äôs two cruise terminals, Canada Place and Ballantyne, are conveniently located and only 30 minutes away from the Vancouver International Airport. Canada Place is located in the city centre, close to shopping, dining, attractions, and Stanley Park. Ballantyne is located east of the city centre and close to Canada Place. The cruise terminals are modern, secure, and world-class.Port Metro VancouverThe Port welcomed 199 ship visits and more than 663,000 revenue passengers at its two cruise terminals, Canada Place and Ballantyne, which offer all the modern conveniences and services for a positive and safe cruise experience.The Capitan‚Ä¶ my Captain!!Canada PlacePort Metro Vancouver‚Äôs premier cruise facility is located in the city centre, at 999 Canada Place near excellent hotels, shopping, dining, entertainment and attractions. Its distinctive white sail design, five-star hotel, and the Vancouver Convention and Exhibition Centre make Canada Place an attractive start and finish to any cruise experience. When we walked through the Convention Centre, Aritzia clothing company, was having a ‚Äòonly once a year‚Äô warehouse sale and swarms of shoppers hit this warehouse sale and were walking around with the Aritzia begs‚Ä¶Canada Place in VancouverBallantyneBallantyne, Port Metro Vancouver‚Äôs second cruise facility, is located at 851 Centennial Road, east of the city centre and just minutes away from Canada Place. The entire terminal underwent a major expansion and renovation in 1995, ensuring modern and efficient services to the cruise industry.Travellers to Ballantyne have access to Ballantyne Cruise Terminal via Clark Drive or McGill Street Overpass only. There is no access to travelers via Victoria Drive and Heatley Avenue.Historic GastownGateway to historic GastownAfter visiting port of Vancouver, we walked several blocks to Gastown. Gastown is where Vancouver originated from. The original part of Vancouver ‚Äì Gastown ‚Äì came about in 1867 after a man named ‚ÄúGassy Jack‚Äù. Deighton opened up a saloon near a lumber mill in the area.Today Gastown itself is a cobble stoned regenerated area with shops as disparate as vintage outlets to the more tourist orientated stores. It‚Äôs also home to the world‚Äôs first steam powered clock, which can still be seen working to this day. It also has some great bars for a night out such as the Lamplighter, the Cork and Fin and the Salt Tasting Room.The most touristy spot is by this steam-powered clockBusy Gastown street with globe-shaped street lampsThe old-world charm of Gastown sits in the middle of the modern city of Vancouver. Gastown is recognized by its cobblestone roads and globe-shaped street lamps. This place has an interesting mix of historical sites, modern upscale housing, souvenir shops, art galleries, restaurants, boutiques and professional offices. Today Gastown has been designated as a heritage site.Busy streets in Gastown areaThere is a landmark in Gastown that is hard to miss. It is a steam-powered clock that sits on the corner of Cambie and Water Street. In 1977, Ray Saunders, a Canadian horologist, was commissioned by the city of Vancouver to build the steam clock to cover a steam grate. It was an honour to be able to have Ray showing me how the clock works. Today, the steam clock attracts thousands of visitors waiting to hear the whistle blow every quarter of an hour. It is also one of the most photographed landmarks in the city.Gastown HistoryEstablished the same year that Canada became a nation, Gastown grew into Canada‚Äôs third largest city and one of its most cosmopolitan. But the Gastown district today retains its historic charm, independent spirit and distinctiveness. There‚Äôs no mistaking Gastown for any other area of Vancouver, or of Canada for that matter.1867: The south shore of Burrard Inlet was a wilderness. Its only non-native settlement was a lumber mill where the owner didn‚Äôt allow alcohol on the premises.One September day, ‚ÄúGassy Jack‚Äù Deighton arrived (he received his nickname because of his penchant for spinning tall tales and talking without end). He stepped ashore with a barrel of whiskey, telling the millworkers that if they‚Äôd build him a saloon, he‚Äôd serve them drinks. The saloon was up and running within a day‚Ä¶just across the property line of the mill. Gastown was born.1870: On March 1st, in order to give it a more distinguished name, Gastown was officially proclaimed to be ‚ÄúGranville‚Äù, after the British colonial secretary. But everybody in the rough and tumble settlement continued to call it Gastown.1886: Gastown was incorporated as the City of Vancouver, after British explorer, George Vancouver. That was April 6th. On June 13th, a brush-clearing fire got out of control and turned all but two of Vancouver‚Äôs 400 buildings to ashes.1920s: Gastown grew and prospered, as did the rest of the City of Vancouver. But good times couldn‚Äôt last forever.Depression Years: Gastown fell on hard times and deteriorated into a stereotypical skid road area until the 1960s.1960s: With talk of demolishing the area becoming more widespread, a group of dedicated citizens took it upon themselves to save Gastown‚Äôs distinctive architecture and character. The city rallied around them. Gastown was not just saved, it was reborn.1971: The provincial government declared Gastown an historic area, protecting its heritage buildings.This steam-powered clock sits on the corner of Cambie and Water StreetToday: Gastown is a refreshing mix of old and new, downhome and upscale, a place for tourists, Vancouver residents and office workers alike. Various shops have the streets buzzing during the day. A host of restaurants and nightspots keeps the area humming into the wee hours. And, more and more, Gastown is becoming home to permanent residents‚Ä¶ just like in the old days.Gastown WebsiteWater St. Caf√©Water St. Caf√©Gastown seems to be a perfect place to rest our tired touristy feet and find a place to sit and have a lunch.
